div.p:
Edgeworths Town Aug[superscript]s[/superscript]. 16th 1844 My dear Doctor Sprague - You have reason to think me the most ungrateful of beings - Yet from your benevolent indulgence I feel assured that you do not condemn me utterly unheard - I received your last kind letter dated Nov[superscript]r[/superscript]. 1[superscript]st[/superscript] first 43 many months ago - but I did not receive the books [unclear]Turnbulls[/unclear] life and the [unclear]N[superscript]os[/superscript].[/unclear] of the Journal of Science for some time afterwards - I was in London with my sister Mrs. Lestock Wilson; staying the winter and spring of the ensuing year with her and being in a whirl- -wind or a whirlpool all the time I was in Town I absolutely had not an hour or half an hour in which I could write a rational letter - The answers to notes of invitation and letters home and visit and the necessity of eating drinking and sleeping absolutely took up every moment - Then I was travelling to various places in the country in England and I did not reach home till May (5[superscript]th[/superscript]) I found your books and [deletion][unclear][/unclear] and[/deletion] was going to write to you when I was taken ill - with Eresipelas I forgot to tell you that I had a very
serious illness the year before as the newspaper truly informed you - [deletion]But[/deletion] The Eresipelas [insertion]which I had in May last[/insertion] though not so dan- gerous as the previous attack [insertion]in 43[/insertion] was alarming enough my pulse being above 100 [deletion]considerably[/deletion] - Providentially however by good nursing and care & skill of a good physician (Sir Henry Marsh of Dublin I [deletion]was[/deletion] recovered - One of my sisters [insertion]nursed me[/insertion] One who never had the pleasure of your acquaintance & whose name Harriet Butler wife of the Rev[superscript]d[/superscript] Richard Butler of Trim may perhaps never have reached you - The most amiable and the most highly informed among our sex are often those whose names are unknown to fame. But instead of writing you this eulogy on my dear sister Harriet I had better finish my own exculpation I have only to add that I was [deletion]so[/deletion] long after this illness forbidden the use of my pen and I am but just now permitted the free use of it - free use I can hardly yet say - for I am often called upon before I have been half an hour with pen in hand called upon by my guardian angels desiring me to lay it down and not to tire myself to [underline]death[/underline] - My friends are really too careful of me - but I am not killed with kindness
I am only vexed that I cannot write to thank my absent and distant friends for favors - I have never [insertion]since my illness[/insertion] written one line yet of what I had begun to write before - I have written only letters and scarcely any letters except to my own family or the particular friends in London who were urgent for replies to their inquiries about my health - `Joanna Baillie and M[superscript]rs[/superscript]. Marcet for instance and Dr. Hollands wife Sidney Smith's daughter Must I name Sidney Smith to an American? Yes surely as you are not one of the Repudiators you probably are not offended by the truth or by the wit and humor of his remarks I saw something of him [deletion]and[/deletion] [underline]behind[/underline] the scenes, as I may say, during my visit to London - I saw him at his daughters quite at his ease - not playing Wit and then he was peculiarly agreeable I think him a very amiable affection ate and truly benevolent man And at his own residence, [insertion][unclear]Coomb Flowry[/unclear][/insertion] & in his own parish he is I am assured quite adored And the person who last told me so was one worthy of credit and one able to judge herself a most amiable woman Lady Bell - widow of the celebrated Sir Charles Bell the Surgeon - [insertion]whose man[superscript][unclear][/unclear][/superscript] are just re- [unclear]embarked[/unclear] by her May Read than[/insertion] I think you are too severe upon (Col[superscript]l[/superscript] Turnbulls Memoirs - M.[superscript]rs[/superscript]. Edgeworth and I have found many parts of them very
4 interesting - all those parts of his personal narratives in London & Paris, and every where when he describes dramatic ally and from the life truly and exactly what he saw and heard of the various characters he met with - especially in revolutionary France - [deletion]The[/deletion] [unclear]facts[/unclear] are always interesting to human creatures & as part of the history of human nature Facts that illustrate the characters of celebrated indiv -duals are always valuable & valued Even the most trivial words and actions for instance of such persons as Talleyrand Madame de Staël [unclear]Duvret[/unclear] &c - [insertion][unclear]long[/unclear][/insertion] posterity will read with curiosity [unclear]while[/unclear] all the long letters and pious justifi[unclear][/unclear] touching only by gone politics or private intrigues of diplomatists are useless & tiresome and the [unclear]exercise[/unclear] of the books there remain [unclear]unread even[/unclear] by the present generation & may [deletion]prevent[/deletion] by the size & weight how much they Twill the volume prevent its going to posterity - The beautiful sketches with which the book is ornamented will do much however to preserve it in the houses and libraries of every person of any taste for the Arts - Thank you my dear Sir for sending me the Book which has amused me more than I could have expected when first I saw its bulk & [deletion][unclear][/unclear][/deletion] felt its weight - Your American books are in general heavier than ours of the same sizes probably from the paper being the [unclear][/unclear] - you print beautifully when you chuse so to do - And most shabbily & on vile paper when are only looking to cheapness & supplying the [unclear]amusement[/unclear] of the day & hours I have An American copy of Helen which is on the worst paper conceivable & squeezed into the smallest compass and [unclear]worst[/unclear] type - But still I am thankful that the Americans republished it at all - You ask me about a forthcoming novel There is no [underline]Forthcoming[/underline] Novel by Maria E - I am writing a tale [insertion]but I have been so interrupted by illness - London - &c &c &c [unclear] I know not[/unclear] whether it will ever be finished -[/insertion] [underline]of which[/underline] you say the newspaper assure - I believe that paragraph must have been put in to newspaper by Bentley who has just [underline]re[/underline]published in one volume my father's memoirs which I have cut down to one volume, by taking out all that I thought su- perfluous in the volume which [underline]I[/underline] wrote - I have not touched my fathers part - Exactly upon the principle which I suggested w[superscript]d[/superscript] be advantageous to Col[superscript]l[/superscript] Turnbull
5 Memoirs, I left in my fathers all that was person al narrative and which I felt was interesting and had been assured the public [unclear]so found[/unclear] - Bentley was not anxious to publish my abridg- ment of these Memoirs fearing there would not be demand for them at the present day - and he made an effort to engage me to promise him "[underline]a for[/underline]thcoming novel" were his very words which he understood he said I was writing I told him that I had no novel ready to come out and that I never bargained for any work till it was completed - and that I would not enter into any engagement for what I am writing or bind myself in any way to finish it or to give it to him - But that when finished I would give him the first offer of the book or that if I die & consent to be published my execu tor should give him the first offer - I have [underline]bored[/underline] you with this long story because you have persuaded me that you are so much interested for me and [insertion]all[/insertion] my doings, and [unclear]works[/unclear] that I felt irresistibly tempted to bore you through and through - I send you a huge packet of auto graphs which I hope will cost you nothing else they will cost you more than they are worth - At your suggestion I have sent you some papers (de trop) of the story which I am now writing and while I had [unclear][/unclear] - I have now cut the pages into slips for your convenience of giving away to your autograph lovers - and I have written my name and the date of the year at the bottom of each for I was anxious to do whatever you wish in this small matter - the only opportu nity I have [deletion]for[/deletion] of shewing my sense of your continued attentions and really valuable gifts to me [insertion](and among the most valuable I count y[superscript]r[/superscript] time in writing to me - You who have so much of correspondence to do for so many[/insertion] Your account of the Associations of Young Men for mutual improvement is highly creditable to your part of the country and will no doubt operate happily upon [insertion]literary[/insertion] society and on moral conduct in the succeeding
6 generations - I heard much of "[underline]Young England[/underline]" when I was in London - I do not know how to explain or define to you what is meant by young England - M[superscript]r[/superscript]. Milne a young [underline]fashionable[/underline] [unclear]&[/unclear] poet in London - a diner out And a speaker in parliament who has obtained [insertion]early[/insertion] celebrity or at least notoriety in all these lines of life is at the head or thinks himself at the head of Young England - They profess to be moral, religious, honorable and chivalrous - not to be [underline]utilitarians[/underline] (those are their particular detastation - Not to be high Churchmen - quite - but to support Church & State - not to be P[unclear][/unclear] ites - - quite - but to be liberal & not too liberal to [unclear]P[/unclear] liberal to Catholics also - but [unclear][/unclear] to Catholics [underline]If[/underline] they could keep their enthusiasm & conduct up to the high tone of morality they profess and if they could stand steady on the broad stone of honor without antics or bravadoing & [underline]if[/underline] they could keep clear of party spirit, affectation & [underline]puppyism[/underline] they would do a wonderful deal of good & would deserve the highest honors of their country - But here are many ifs, and difficulties which not one [unclear][/unclear] said of "Young [underline]England - it is[/underline]" ever thought of when they adopted the apella- -tion and above all), - the dress -. How would you Young England know England [deletion][unclear][/unclear][/deletion] Why by his open breast or open shirt collar [deletion][unclear][/unclear][/deletion] -collar to this says in truth he must have none - but [deletion][unclear][/unclear][/deletion] his shirt must turn down at the neck which school boys or I am told, in imitation of the ancient [underline]Romans[/underline] (who had no shirts) - If the gentle man does not chuse to bare his neck and shews himself like Lord Byrons picture if he will wear a neck kerchief cravat or
7 by whatever name it should be called it must be [underline]white[/underline] - "Down with Black Collars" as it was cried by the Paris mob to your Col[superscript]l[/superscript]. Turnbull in 97 - when he ran from them & wisely tore off his coat & burned it rather than be mobbed - [deletion][unclear][/unclear][/deletion] Benites the white neck cloth or bare neck Young England is to be known by his long hair streaming over his face and shoulders - curled or uncurled - Black Brown or Red so it must be worn - natural or false so it must be or you cannot be a young England - much of their strength is in their hair - But I am writing upon them much more of my paper than I can afford I am sorry to hear of burglaries in your city - In spite of your intellectual improvements - How is this? Does moral conduct not follow from intellectual cultivation The subject [unclear][/unclear] question interests me much - The object of the tale I am now writing or thinking of writing is to shew that those who attempt to improve the education and condition of the [underline]poor[/underline] ([unclear][/unclear] we [underline]have[/underline] poor in our country) or of the lower classes in any country must take special care that the moral education keeps pace with the intellectual else they do more good than harm to society and do not increase the real happiness of the individuals - my heroine is to be raised from Town life - and the [underline]benevolent[/underline] lady [deletion][unclear][/unclear][/deletion] gives her all manner of accomplishments but forgets principles and does not prepare her temper for the trials she must meet with in her sudden rise in life - nor does she [deletion][/deletion] teach her the self-control whicn in her motherless state is peculiarly necessary to enable her to resist the temptations to which a young beauty parvenue is exposed - As far as concerns my heroine [insertion]& her patroness[/insertion] only you cannot except for my sake my dear Sir be much interested in all this - But perhaps your daughter [insertion]or Mrs Sprague[/insertion] may & may have heard of facts and
8 examples that would be useful to me to know - I mean in the course of the story (if I can to shew that unless great precautions are taken in the preparation of the individual raised [underline]per saltem[/underline] in life, there is a bad chance of the rise in condition being for their happiness I shall touch upon the cure that ought to be taken by patrons & patronesses of charita ble schools both to keep the moral ed.[superscript]n[/superscript] equal to the intellectual and also to make the motives for industry and for the acquirement of knowledge, pure and good - not connected with envy as emulation is to apt to be - and not [insertion]merely[/insertion] springing from [underline]avarice[/underline] or [underline]worldly[/underline] [underline]ambition[/underline] - Those motives are subject to great disappointments & to lead at all times to heart burnings if nothing worse and to unhappiness within if not in out- ward circumstances or appearances. [deletion]My [unclear][/unclear][/deletion] I was called away as I was writing this to go to see a show on the Green at the end of the village - a show of Elephant & horses and horseman ship - and M[superscript]rs[/superscript]. E whom you know, and another M[superscript]rs[/superscript]. E whom you dont know, my brother Francis's wife, a Spanish lady [deletion]who not[/deletion] who has now five children who form the whole family at Edgeworths town [insertion]& all[/insertion] went to see the show - The children all have the hooping cough but the entertainment [deletion][unclear][/unclear][/deletion] operated so powerfully that they never once hooped during the hour we were there - I was never better entertained tho I have seen [insertion]fine[/insertion] exhibitions of horsemanship in Dublin & London - I was surprised to see in the first place the size & magnificence of the Tent - One hundred & forty feet circumference! Seats all round the circus raised four rows & covered with painted cloth like carpets We saw [deletion]two[/deletion] [insertion]a[/insertion] most graceful and active youth ride two horses abreast - one foot on one the other foot on the other horse round & round the center pole of the tent - then four in hand - Then two young men full canter [deletion][unclear][/unclear][/deletion] - One standing on the others shoulder! & waiving hands & arms A large village audience had assembled and among those [insertion]of the upper class[/insertion]were the protestant clergyman &
clergyman & his sister who went with us - and the Catholic priest - I was very glad to see them both sitting on the same bench and enjoying & sanctioning these innocent diversions - Several pretty young girls were there and I am sure enjoyed as much real pleasure as if they had been finely dressed and raised from their [deletion]rank[/deletion] humble stations to be young ladies in high life & sitting at a grand theatre in London - perhaps envious or jealous of the dress or beauty or high birth of somebody opposite to them or in the same box - The elephant was as good at Edgeworths town as in London and ran his rational recreations over as well as if he were exhibiting at the Tower or the Zoological Gardens - And now my dear D[superscript]r[/superscript]. Sprague I think you will say I have written enough and very glad shall I be if you think that I have made up for long silence & ingratitude I really am your grateful and much obliged Maria Edgeworth I continue to find Sillimans journal a most interesting book - Doctor Robinson professor of astronomy and Astronomer Royal, Armagh and one of our first men of science and of genius much admires this American Journal & I have the pleasure of lending it to him - He is married to my sister Lucy - married her last year - a marriage in which all her family rejoiced - she had been for years in bad health confined by a spine complaint - which she bore with exemplary fortitude & sweet patience - She is now in the [unclear]enjoyment[/unclear] of as perfect happiness and health as can be - I have said nothing of the books we have been reading - I should have told you that we have been reading Prescott Conquest of Mexico - the most interesting book I have seen this century - I am now hearing it read for the second time - I read it during my convalescence & immediately on my return home found my brother is reading it [insertion]& I Sharing it[/insertion] over again with the greatest delight
1 3/4 oz The Rev[superscript]d[/superscript] Doctor Sprague Albany New York Sep 19
